senses.de: A person who offers to do something without being paid.
senses.ex: She is a volunteer in a charity organization.

Tips.title: Altruistic Connotation
Tips.description: The term conveys a sense of selflessness, often associated with helping others or supporting causes.
Tips.example: Volunteers at the hospital are valued for their altruism.

Tips.title: Not Compulsory
Tips.description: 'Volunteer' implies that the action is done by choice rather than obligation.
Tips.example: She became a volunteer, though no one required her to.

Tips.title: Community Involvement
Tips.description: Volunteering is often linked with community service and civic engagement.
Tips.example: As a volunteer, he felt more connected to his community.

senses.de: To offer to do something without being paid or without being asked.
senses.ex: He volunteered to wash the dishes.

Tips.title: Initiative Shown
Tips.description: Shows willingness to take initiative and contribute without being prompted.
Tips.example: He volunteered to lead the fundraising event.

Tips.title: Positive Impression
Tips.description: Volunteering can leave a positive impression, showcasing enthusiasm and proactivity.
Tips.example: She volunteered for the task and impressed her teachers.

Tips.title: Pre-emptive Offer
Tips.description: Indicates offering help before someone asks for it.
Tips.example: When he saw the workload, he volunteered immediately.

senses.de: Doing or being done without being paid or forced to do it.

Tips.title: Optional Participation
Tips.description: Emphasizes that participation is done by choice and without monetary incentives.
Tips.example: She took on a volunteer role in the event.

Tips.title: Informal Nature
Tips.description: May indicate a less formal context or arrangement than official employment.
Tips.example: As a volunteer tutor, he didn't need a formal contract.

Tips.title: Flexibility
Tips.description: Volunteer positions often offer flexibility in terms of time and commitment.
Tips.example: Volunteer opportunities can be more adaptable to your schedule.

senses.de: A plant that grows without being deliberately planted.
senses.ex: These tomatoes are volunteers from last year's crop.

Tips.title: Unplanned Growth
Tips.description: Refers to plants that grow on their own, without human intention or action.
Tips.example: The garden has several volunteer plants this season.

Tips.title: Ecology Insight
Tips.description: Offers insight into local ecology by indicating which plants grow naturally.
Tips.example: Volunteer species in a garden may show the local habitat's preference.

Tips.title: No Human Selection
Tips.description: The plants have not been selected or bred by humans, which might result in genetic diversity.
Tips.example: Volunteer veggies in our garden might not look perfect, but they're hardy.

Assist.wordDefinition:
Assist means to give help or support to someone who needs it.

Assist is applicable in situations where someone needs help with a specific task, while volunteer is applicable in situations where people want to offer their time and energy to help out their community or a cause they support.

Contribute.wordDefinition:
Contribute means to provide or donate something, like money or supplies, to a cause or organization. It usually involves giving something valuable to help make something happen.

Both words can be used in different situations. For example, you might contribute money to a charity to help them reach their fundraising goal, or you might volunteer your time to help run a fundraiser event.

The main difference is that contributing usually involves giving something valuable, while volunteering involves giving your time and effort.

Enlist.wordDefinition:
Enlist means to join a group or organization, usually in a formal way, like enlisting in the military or joining a sports team.

Enlisting is often applicable when joining a structured organization with specific requirements, such as joining the military, whereas volunteering is applicable when offering help or services for a specific cause or organization, such as volunteering at a charity or community event.

Help out.wordDefinition:
Help out usually refers to assisting someone with a task or chore that they are already doing, whereas volunteer refers to offering your time and skills to a cause or organization without expecting anything in return.

For example, if your friend needs help cleaning their room, you can help out by joining in and doing some of the cleaning with them.

If you volunteer at a local animal shelter, you are committing your time and energy to help the shelter care for animals in need.

Help out is more applicable in personal situations, where you are lending a hand to a friend or family member. Volunteer is more applicable in communal settings such as organizations or charities, where you are giving back to the community by committing your time and effort.

Join up.wordDefinition:
Join up usually refers to becoming a member of a group, organization or team by officially signing up or registering for it.

It is often used in the context of helping others or contributing to a cause without compensation. For example, people can volunteer to clean up a park or help out at a soup kitchen.

Join up implies becoming a member of a specific organization, while volunteer involves offering one's time, skills, or resources to help others.

Offer.wordDefinition:
Offer means to suggest or present something to someone, often as a solution or assistance, and could be in exchange for something else.

For example, "I can offer to help you with your homework if you help me with my project."

Volunteer means to offer one's time, services, or effort without expecting anything in return. For example, "I want to volunteer at the soup kitchen this weekend to help people in need.".

Offer is applicable when someone wants to suggest help or something of value for some kind of exchange, whereas volunteer is applicable when someone wants to help or contribute without any expectation of getting something in return.

Pitch in.wordDefinition:
Pitch in means to help out or contribute to a group effort, usually when something needs to be done. For example, if your family is cleaning the house, you can pitch in by vacuuming the living room or washing the dishes.

Volunteer means to offer to do something without being asked, usually for a specific cause or organization. For example, you can volunteer at a food bank to help pack meals for people in need.

Both pitch in and volunteer involve helping others, but pitch in is more informal and implies that there is already a group effort happening, while volunteer involves actively seeking out ways to help a specific cause or organization.

Serve.wordDefinition:
Serve refers to performing a duty or task that is required or expected of someone, usually within a formal setting such as a job or military service.

For example, a waiter serves food to customers or a soldier serves their country.

Serve typically implies a formal obligation or job duty, while volunteer implies a choice to perform a helpful act without expectation of payment or reward.

quotes.Text: Looking in a mirror and telling yourself to feel better doesn't work when you're a girl, but finding something that you love to do, something that makes you a better person like volunteering to help others, will definitely make a difference.
quotes.Title: South Korean Journalist
quotes.Name: Su-chin Pak

quotes.Text: We all have a responsibility to volunteer somewhere and I'm lucky that I get the education and get taken to places to see what's out there and see what's happening and to then be a part of it in hopefully an impactful way.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Jennifer Garner

quotes.Text: I do a lot for PETA. I do a lot of things I think are really important, I volunteer at school and I'm still amazed I can pay my bills because I feel like I don't work that much, I really don't.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Pamela Anderson

quotes.Text: Volunteering is a great way to look outside your own problems. Giving back to makes you happier by both giving you a sense of purpose and helping to put your problems in perspective.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Karen Salmansohn

quotes.Text: I do try to be of some use in the world. I sometimes do volunteer work with kids, and manage to help some people a little, but really making a significant difference can be hard.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: John Shirley

quotes.Text: I live in the country. I'm a bird-watcher, an oyster-raiser. You know, I'll do anything that - raise dogs for the blind as a volunteer.
quotes.Title: Italian Actress
quotes.Name: Isabella Rossellini

quotes.Text: Whatever your cause, whatever your motivation, I hope you'll agree with me that volunteer service is an extraordinary gift.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Neil Bush

quotes.Text: The best way to appreciate our political process is to volunteer for a campaign and support a candidate you believe in.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Rob McKenna

quotes.Text: It's amazing to me the number of people who will volunteer to help at church but won't lift a finger to help at home!
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Joyce Meyer

quotes.Text: Yeah, I volunteered to support the troops, and get out there and show them that we care about them.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Gary Sinise
